description:
ST REGIS HOTEL is my favorite hotel in San Francisco. It always proves to be a place of serenity, elegance, first class service and hospitality. I have a tradition of visiting the SFMOMA, so having the St. Regis next door makes for a quick and easy visit. 

The hotel room and bathroom are spacious. There is a desk and vanity area, as well as spacious closets. The feel is modern, streamlined, and the hotel atmosphere is subdued and peaceful. By the way, the hotel is a few blocks away from Yank Sing, my favorite place for dim sum! Win-win!! 

One of their services I'm looking forward to trying is their version of Afternoon Tea. Absolutely love this hotel!
author: Elaine O.

description:
This review is for their Art of Tea Afternoon Tea Service. 

I've had my fair share of afternoon teas in SF and London and was initially weary of this location after reading some mix reviews, but decided to give it a try anyways. I consider myself an afternoon tea snob and prefer going to tea service that have modern and elegant ambiance, with aesthetics in their food and presentation to match. St. Regis, definitely did not disappoint and is now my favorite afternoon tea spot in SF (savory, sweets, service, ambiance).     

I took my BFF here to celebrate her birthday and we opted for the regular tea without the alcohol $69/person (before tax and tips).  

AMBIANCE: 
The tea is in the hotel lobby/bar area which has very modern and clean vibe. We were seated at parallel sofas with a coffee table in between us giving it a very relaxed and chill vibe, but also a little weird to eat with such a low table. 

TEA/FOOD: 
We were given different types of tea leaves to sniff and choose from. The tea came in a French press and a set of timers, which was pleasantly new to me. The savory and sweets came out at the in a beautifully presented triangle display with a colorful array of small assorted bites. Unlike, a lot of afternoon tea places, they had a variety of savory bites - not just sandwiches. They were all very food and flavorful, though pretty small. I enjoyed all the sweets! Every single one! All the high tea places I've been to, either underwhelmed me with at least 1-2 of their selections or just had overly sweet pastries. We especially enjoyed their jalapeno corn bread with corn cream. The only thing missing from their selection are scones! They offered jam and cream, but no scones! Where are the scones?

SERVICE: 
10/10. Our server went above the beyond for our service! Very attentive and friendly.  

Verdict: Had a great experience, but for $69+ we expected at least some additional scones. But their savory and sweet selection were nearly perfect.
author: Samantha F.

description:
I normally wouldn't come here, but a friend was staying here for the week so we went to grab a drink and some dessert.

The level of service and accommodation and the ambiance of the bar is top notch.  It is a classy place and they will do all that they can to make your visit pleasant.

The lobby bar is way overpriced and not really worth it.  Simple mixed drinks are in the mid to high teens as far as price.  I got a moscow mule that wasn't very tasty.  Whatever they used for the ginger component was not very good at all, I would not get that drink again, it was very disappointing and my friend had the same and thought the same as I did.
author: Ty C.

description:
This review is for their Chinese New Year afternoon tea service and their champagne sabering evening ritual.  

I learned early this year that St Regis offers high tea service at their lobby bar.  My friend and I love high teas and made reservation to try right the way.  It was the Chinese New Year celebration month therefore the high tea menu was special with Chinese dim sums.  We were excited about the Chinese New Year special high tea menu.  Unfortunately the dim sums did not meet our high expectation.  The flavors were delicious.  The ingredients tasted fresh and the dim sum wraps/buns tasted housemade.  The only disappointing element of these dim sums is the thick dim sum wraps/buns.  They looked good, just not delicate nor tasted delicate the quality dim sums my friend and I anticipated.

I love their selections of teas and our waiter's service that day!  He was courteous and patient with my questions for the teas they serve.  The pastries/scones/macaroons/finger sweets were delicious!  I would definitely go back for their regular high service menu.

We also learned that day about their champagne sabering evening ritual on Thursday, Friday, and Saturday at 6pm.  It was fun watching the champagne sabering ceremony.  I brought a few visitors there for this unique experience.
author: Gina W.

description:
This review is solely for the lobby bar, as I have not stayed in one of the rooms!
My friend spoke very highly of this place and asked if I wanted to come by on a Thursday afternoon. To my surprise, there were a lot of people for 3pm. Decor is modern and classy much like other hotel lobbies. It was very bright and roomy.
I wasn't able to try the afternoon tea set but I did try their teas, snacks, and desserts. Maybe next time!
I tried their English Breakfast tea and I love that they give you an actual tea press and with refills!! I was pretty hungry so I ordered their fried chicken tenders but it was quite good. The desserts were definitely the highlight!! The opera cake was to DIE for.... It's rare that places really nail their opera cakes. We also ordered the orange? mousse cake. I normally don't order something like this but my friend really recommended it and it was nice. 
I will definitely be back to try their afternoon tea sets though!!
author: Kristie L.

description:
A disappointing Afternoon Tea experience. Though Milan, the Server, went above and beyond for his excellent service. Food quality however was horribly disappointing. At $69 a serving, the pastry quality is beyond poor. Among the cakes in the tea serving, the roll cake was stale, cream topping wasn't fresh; the bacon in small croissant bite was simply disgusting! Fruits in the fruit tart were dehydrated. There was also a shrimp wrap and it was loose and fallen apart the moment it was picked up. The list went on:(

The restaurant bar is in a nice hip setting. Of the Two Stars in this review One Star goes to Milan because he truly earned it. The other Star for the ambience and the plate presentation.
author: William Q.

description:
I have a yearly tradition where the day after Thanksgiving I have high tea with friends. This was the first time that I reserved the St. Regis for our holiday tea and it will be the last holiday tea that I have there. When I called to make the reservations I specified the seating that I wanted. The individual at the reservations desk advised that it wouldn't be a problem. When I received the confirmation call I verified the seating again and advised of a seafood allergy. It was weird that the holiday menu had all seafood tea sandwiches and not one traditional tea sandwich.

When my friends and I showed up they had us seated in the wrong area and definitely with the wrong server. She comes over to take our order I advise that only 2 are having the full tea services and 2 were just having tea. She looks at us and didn't know what to say??? Annoying.....I confirm with her that there is a seafood allergy and that I will just take the traditional tea service instead of the holiday menu.... again blank stare...uhm yea this is when the server is suppose say " yes I do see that there is a note specifying a seafood allergy".... "your tower will be right out"....instead she said that she didn't know if it could be replaced......huh!@&#...not to mention that both menu options were posted on the website as well as the reservationist sent me the PDF for both Holiday and Traditional Tea menus. I requested for the manager to come over because I wasn't getting anywhere with clueless. The manager comes over, I had to explain it again. He's trying to explain how it's suppose to be..... which is something different than what was confirmed with me...... I told him that we were on our way to dinner after tea so we only wanted 2 towers. I could appreciate his suggestions but at some point you have to know when to quit while you're ahead. He said since we didn't want 4 towers for there. He could have 2 packed to go......Da Fuq. So...what? We're supposed to pay $140.00 for you to box up 4 sandwiches and a few sweets. Not to mention, there wasn't going to be any tea included and carry this to dinner with us and by the time we get home it's either mush or hard as biscuits?.....What a joke. Except I didn't laugh. Ok so we finally start our tea service, nothing special... (some things are meant to stay simple and be perfected )we probably should have left after our first cups of tea because our server took an extremely long time to refresh our hot water. It's like she didn't want to or knew how to serve us and tried to leave us hanging, like we would just go away....so again we didn't go away, we just won't be back. 2 other servers assisted us and were very nice and quick. Gawd I can go on.....it's clear that I wasn't a fan.
author: Stacie J.

description:
This review is for afternoon tea, which is offered everyday from 2-4pm with at least 24 hour advance reservations.  They will take a credit card number when you call, ask if you have any food allergies, and inform you of their 24-hour cancellation policy to avoid any charges.  The cost is $65 per person and goes up if you choose some bubbly to go along with your tea.  Pretty pricey, but it seems to be the going rate for tea service in the fancy hotels in the area.  Service was professional and courteous, and the ambiance nice.  We were seated in a cozy spot with couch seating by the fire.  Expect to see mostly tourists and business travelers here.  

You can visit the St. Regis website to view the food menu and look at the tea options.  I would have to say portions were pretty small for the price of the tea service.  The savories were ok, but I think I preferred the sweets.  (It's usually the other way around for me.)  They have samples of tea that you can smell to help you decide what to order.  I like fruity teas so I went with the Mountain Berry which I liked.  

FYI: if you are driving here, you can park in the garage on Mission St. that is just about a block away.  

Afternoon Tea in the St. Regis Lobby Lounge is one of the more expensive options in town but a nice once-in-awhile splurge for the experience.
author: Carnita M.

description: The lobby bar is our go-to spot for before and after dinner drinks, especially if we're with friends and visitors.  It's next to SFMOMA, Moscone Center, and Union Square, so it's conveniently located.
author: Carlo A.

description: Great bar in a lovely hotel in downtown San Fran. Coming in after an evening out or starting an evening at the bar was wonderful. Friendly staff and great drinks.
author: Bryan M.

description:
The server couldn't have been more polite and sweet, but the food quality and service as a whole was surprisingly poor.

For those prices, I would expect much, much more.
author: Jane D.

description: Went after visiting MOMA.  The bar area is great.  The service is great.  The food is OK, but a little pricey.  But here's the thing - the drink menu is a little misleading.  It lists prices - but SOME drinks come with an upcharge.  That's not marked on the menu.  So that $14.00 drink is really $17.00.  The explanation is that some drinks come with more alcohol because they come in a bigger glass, and it would look funny if the glass were only 2/3 full.  Fine - I accept that.  BUT THE MENU should reflect that.  Is $3.00 a big deal?  No.  But it IS the principle.  In the end, Brian, the manager, agreed that it was misleading.  He removed the upcharges, and  that's why the fourth star.  Great environment, great staff, but ask about the prices...
author: Daniel O.

description: Elegant and sophisticated stop on your way to anywhere south of market.  Good lobby bar.  Not pretentious but yet classy...no "k" in that classy either.  Don't be shy with your cocktail order.
author: Darby W.

description:
I love the seating choices in their lobby bar!! They've got the bar seating, two party tables, couch/lounge seat for bigger groups.

As expected, their cocktails were $14-18 each. They've got wine, champs, cocktails, beer, and even dessert drinks. Beers are about $9-11 I think. We didn't try any of their appetizers because we wanted to save our appetite for dinner. I ordered La Pisco. Mine was somewhat strong, which I liked. I sipped on it cause I can't hang anymore lol. Mine was for sure better than what my bf got. Boyfriend ordered a La Pistola. His had one large cube of ice and one slice of jalapeno. I didn't like his at all. My friend and her fiance ordered beers. They provide complimentary snacks--- spicy cheddar popcorn and corn nuts in cute little bowls.

After we had dinner, we sat at the bar to watch the last quarter of the Warriors game. The bartenders were so much more fun and talkative than their waitresses. 

Overall, I loved the ambiance of the place. It was perfect for catching up with my friend and a cute hang out place. I can imagine how convenient it is to have it there in the lobby.
author: Steffi G.

description:
Yelp considers two stars at 'Meh. I've experienced better,' and thats pretty much my exact thoughts after grabbing a quick drink here.

I was grabbing a quickie beer with a friend and this was the closest. I've never been here so I though hey, what the hell and give it a try.

First they were out of the bottle of Dogfish Head I wanted so I got the Sculpin instead.  

$11.

Was I surprised? Not really.  I expected it but not sure why I followed through with it.  When theres so many options a few steps away.

However you would think that for $11 a beer you would have the best service you've ever seen at such a fancy hotel right? 

Nope.

Frowns all around.  

Lastly, even the popcorn was stale.  

So disappointing all around.
author: Hansen L.

description: This is a hands down spot for a really nice cocktail in an upscale, very classy place.  Everything about it is exceedingly beautiful and elegant.  Very comfortable seating and a club like atmosphere.  You can have a wide assortment of cocktails, from the usual, to specialty ones that are quite inventive.  Service is also top notch and the contemporary surroundings are very calming and soothing. Be prepared to fork out a hefty amount for a cocktail, I.e., $16., but well worth it.  For a special occasion or just to grab a nice drink before heading elsewhere I highly recommend it.  Why not 5 stars? Well at times it can get very crowded and then the service slows down too.  Go when you can at least get a comfy place to sit and feel pampered and not rushed to give your seat to someone else.
author: Tom B.

description: Very slick place to hang and grab a drink. Bartenders are always cool and helpful. Plus, they serve complimentary snacks which pair nicely with any beverage. I highly recommend stopping by the St Regis Hotel Lobby Bar for a drink or two... or a few more.  :)
author: Peter C.

description:
This is always my go-to place when in need of a spot to retreat in a hurry. If you're looking for a place that's generally quiet when you just want to relax and have a drink and a talk with your company, this place is perfect. 

The decor is absolutely gorgeous and the service is consistently courteous every time. The whole vibe is just so warm and welcoming that you almost never want to leave.
author: Destini M.

description:
After a long morning of enjoying the art at SF MOMA, the Lobby Bar was a welcome retreat from the crowds. The museum cafe was packed, and this was an excellent escape. 


We ate a late lunch of gorgeous salads and tasty salmon as we sipped champagne and cocktails. I loved the Trans-Siberian cocktail and the popcorn bar snack in particular! 

It was a beautiful room with great food and the excellent service we've come to expect from the St. Regis brand.
author: Shelby D.

description:
Ok food. premium price. 20 for 3 chicken and negi kabab. 22 for a small burger. 10 for a watery garlic fries. 
*Edit* One star for St Regis service, Zero star for the food.
author: Cecile Y.

description: I love the ambience, vibe and decor of the St Regis.  The service at the bar was easy and everything seemed to be no problem--which I love.  I ordered a salad, side of fries and a cocktail...my bill (with tip) was $50!!  OMG!  I knew it was going to be pricey, but I actually laughed out loud because it was definitely not worth the money.  The fries were heavily seasoned with rosemary which I was not a fan of.  Does rosemary go well with french fries?  I cringed with every bite and couldn't even put a dent in them.  I would still go back for the drink and ambience part the next time I'm in the area.
author: Christine T.

description:
Just completed a two day work seminar at the luxurious St. Regis Hotel, in San Francisco....

Approximately 4:00pm on Wednesday, upon completing our course, a fellow co-attendee and I decided to check out the hotel lobby bar, before we hit the dreaded 101 nightmare commute. She wanted coffee. I opted for a diet coke. $14.00 I might add.

It is a swanky, upscale setting in the lobby with a couple of friendly, and talkative bartenders. Comfy seats, overstuffed chairs. Great for people watching!  We grabbed some seats on a couch in front of the fireplace. 

A pretencious businessman appeared suddenly, and was talking loud (to anyone who would listen) about the current Republican regime. As he was drinking, and flaunting the American Express Centurion Card (Yes...the titanium black card), he offered to buy everyone in the lobby a drink. Before I knew it, another diet coke appeared before me, and at the same time, the hotel staff was escorting the guest to his room.  The bartender seemed relieved.  I was running low on the complimentary snack (nuts) and decided to hit the road. An hour at the swanky bar was enough.

Now I know why my diet coke was $$$.  Have to pay for that hotel security somehow. Told you it's a classy hotel. No riff raff allowed.
author: Janet T.

description:
What can I say but amazing!  
great place to enjoy the view and food was on par with the expectations.
author: William D.

description: I had high tea with friends on 12/16/17 and it was the most mediocre and over-priced I have ever had. I'm not typically one to write negative reviews but I found this experience so outrageous that I almost called them the next day to complain! I'm also not typically one to complain about the amount of food served because I'm willing to pay quite a bit of money for a delicious meal, but this was just unacceptable. 4 teeny tiny bites of food for the savory courses and 4 overly sweet and Trader Joe's quality sweets for the other half of the courses. The tea, I will admit, was very nice. Lastly, we sat at a table right by the gas fireplace and it smelled like natural gas throughout our meal (this one isn't really their fault but I'm sure there has to be a way to avoid that). I've been to a lot of high teas and have always enjoyed them, this was the first time I found it to be a complete disappointment in terms of food quality. I wouldn't recommend it to anyone and will definitely not be coming back.
author: Fleur R.

description: There are times when you just need a hotel bar/cafe to lounge in. So far my experience with St. Regis Hotel Lobby Bar has been decent. We once waited a bit for a table to clear out but that wasn't an issue. A good dependable place to have in mind in case you're not looking for anything in particular.
author: Yad L.

description:
Calling the St. Regis Lobby Bar my neighborhood go-to spot for imbibing adult beverages sounds pretty pretentious, no? But it's just a matter of geography.

My experiences there have been crazy reliable... as in, the St. Reg always delivers exactly what I want - a relaxed atmosphere with comfy, copious seating; a diverse selection of drink, wine, and beer; and fantastic food.

Recently, I came here with a group of my friends for some belated birthday drinks. I was able to enjoy two of my favorite things: craft beer and cake. So Baked Alaska doesn't actually qualify as cake, but how many places can you find this elusive dessert? And definitely get the pork buns; they're money.

On a Saturday night, the bar is typically quiet making it a wonderful spot to punctuate the end of a date with a nightcap or conversely, it's a space capable of accommodating a largish group in a pinch. Cheers!
author: Jelena Z.

description:
***************************** 1412 ***************************

  The cocktails are good and strong here. The food is good here and solid. The bartenders, service was a hit or a miss for me. I used to come here often when my clients were in Soma. Since I changed my career a few years back. I don't come here anymore. I do miss my corporate credit card :-)

  St. Regis bar is a beautiful, modern, and inviting lounge & bar. It was 1 of my favorite places for a cocktail or 2 after work before.

 I stayed-cation here this month SEPT 2015. When I sat at the lounge. Our waitress was very nice, the drink and food came out nicely. 

  Next day, when I took my niece and nephew down to the bar for some mocktails. I asked the barman to make it just a little spicy mocktail. He made it overly spicy. Obviously he didn't taste the drink before he handed to us.

  I asked him to made a drink for my friend first because we were on a scheduled to head out for dinner at Saison. The over 6 FT tall barman gave me an attitude. I was shocked, but I didn't say anything. Good thing he was good looking and my cocktail was very good. I still tipped the dude 30%, charged to my room.

  It was sad that I experienced this kind of service at the St. Regis on this stay.

P.S. Valet Parking is about $62 per day, if you just come here for a meeting or lunch, expect to pay at least $25 for an hour or 2.
author: Manda Bear B.

description: I've had two experiences at this hotel bar, and, while it's a beautiful setting for a drink, I've found on both occasions that the service is lacking. On the good side, someone will generally come around right away with bar snacks and to take an order. Once you receive drinks, however, you may need to send up a flare in order to get someone to bring either a second round or your check. On top of this, drinks are outrageously expensive. That's to be expected from a high-end hotel bar, but there are plenty of other nice bars in the area to grab a drink.
author: Michelle C.

description:
Stopped by here for drinks - pricey at $20/each but whaddya expect from a nice place.
Delicious cucumber gin drink. They muddle the basil which was a great touch. Great place for a formal date night and/or with friends who don't mind spending a bit more for well made drinks at a nice place.
author: Mio W.

description: Still great place for a drink and a classy (and pricey) cocktail.  The food now comes from the Grill which unfortunately is a far cry from the Michelin starred Ame restaurant that closed.  Come for the drinks and ambience, great cocktail and wine selection and very knowledgeable and friendly bartenders.
author: Kenneth L.

description:
Such a cute but classy place to grab a drink. Was having dinner at Ame last Wednesday as an early Father's Day celebration and had some time to kill before my reservation. Grabbed a seat on the couch in front of the fireplace.

Our waitress was on it and quickly got us a menu and snacks. The complimentary snacks were an Asian snack mix. We got a glass of Schramsberg blanc de blancs north coast 2011 ($17) and a Jack daniels and diet coke ($14). You are at the St Regis so the drinks aren't cheap. But it is a nice place to have a drink or two while enjoying the ambiance and some good conversation with your drinkmate!
author: Elena N.

description: You guys... this bar is amazing. Top notch staff who is not only knowledgeable but also down to earth and relatable. Eric, Mathew, Ben and Ricardo will take excellent care of you. But don't forget this is St. Regis... the menu is chock full of all the right choices :) enjoy!
author: Dannielle F.

description:
I like this bar/lounge. Very cozy and not too loud. 

You can order drinks from the bar or other beverages and food. All non-alkie items come from Ame. Their Earl Gray tea is the best I've had so far. Their beignets were fluffy and hit the spot. BFF had wine and it was a generous pour.
author: Julie L.

description: We had afternoon tea with Manika as our waitress and she was amazing! So sweet, so polite. Just a gem. We felt very comfortable and well taken care of. We will be back.
author: Claire S.

description: As others have mentioned, the lobby at the St. Regis is a welcome retreat from the hustle and bustle of the atea around 3rd and Mission. Drinks are expensive but you can sit in the lobby off the bar for free.
author: Martin C.

description:
came here for the foie gras ramen last night! YUMMM! it was our second time trying to get it, cuz last week they were out of foie gras! crazy!

anyhoo, the bar is really nice, quiet despite it being prime happy hour time.  there were men dressed in suits everywhere. the service is attentive and friendly, although sometimes a bit slow? there are a lot of drink orders to take! haha so no worries. 

probably would not come for a casual drink because of the prices and given the options around that area, buttt the ramen was good! and i would go back for that :)
author: Christina L.

description:
My friend and I had a lovely afternoon sipping cocktails at the bar. What made it such a pleasurable experience was Jose, our bartender. He is a delightful man with an excellent knowledge of spirits. 

He walked us through several types of tequila and cognac including Louis the thirteenth. We learned a lot and felt warm and fuzzy the rest of the day.

Thank you, Jose!
author: Shelley C.

description:
Stopped in for a nightcap after a concert while we were staying here. The bar was empty on a Saturday night at 12am. I understand because there are a lot of great options in San Francisco and a hotel bar, though a really really nice hotel bar, just doesn't make the cut.

The drink menu is interesting and well curated. The bartender who served us was super nice and fun to talk to. He was engaging enough but didn't talk our ear off.

I can't remember what I had but it was something in a wine glass akin to a manhattan and I really enjoyed it.
author: Ryan L.

description:
+Very friendly wait staff that recommended a nice white wine
+lovely decor, comfortable couches, and nice location

I would definitely come here for drinks again :)
author: Jenni H.

description:
We were staying at the St. Regis and stopped by the Lobby Bar for some quick bites before an event.  While I didn't stay long, I still had a good experience here.

Tried:  

Bloody Mary - The only BM I've ever had that was clear and not red.  still tasted the part.  served in a martini glass. was good but not a favorite of mine

Fried Oyster sliders - fried just right.  I would order these again

Pulled pork bun - pretty tasty.  no complaints

Fries - Just right.  Great fries!


Service:  great service.  very attentive here
author: Marcus L.

description:
One of my favorite "local" bars. I know it's a hotel bar but I can always find a seat, the wait staff is always fast and friendly...and the pours are quite generous. They provide little snacks - wasabi peas and some other crunchy Asian mix item (I don't know what it is) - but it's always nice to have some bar snacks during happy hour.

As you can imagine, drinks are not cheap - glasses of wine are $12-$14 - but it's worth it for the top-notch service and comfortable surroundings. They have great seating and lots of it.
author: Wendy L.

description: Came here when it first opened (many, many, many years ago) and was here again recently.  Great space, selection of drinks, and fast service.  Chairs are comfortable, many places to sit, and not overly loud.  Not as much of a 'party' like the W Hotel bar.
author: Angelica C.

description:
This is my sis's token "let's meet up for cocktails" before dinner go-to spot. Thus, I'm spoiled.

S.O. and I waited for the sis to arrive... we managed to get a couch and that's surprising for a Saturday night. 

Service is prompt and friendly... I ordered two sidecars for the sis and I and the S.O. just had a Stella. 

They give you almonds... Asian crackers and deep fried edamame while sipping on your drink.

Our sidecar wasn't good BUT they do have Hanger One so they're awesome in my book! 

We'll be back for sure!
author: Cath M.

description: Came here on a Wednesday night. Not too crowded; great for catching up as the noise level is minimal. Excellent wine selection and great menu.  Little pricey, but it is the St. Regis.
author: Coco B.

description: Took a break for some tea and champagne in the lobby and felt really chill and enjoyed our time. Our server was so sweet. Both the Champange and tea were delicious and the little nibblys were tasty to. Nice and quiet atmosphere with a warm and soothing fireplace.
author: Aviana V.

description:
Came back for their drinks! Earlier than expected, but good nevertheless. My colleague and I came here after Jersey Boys Wednesday night and sat from around 11 pm - 12:30 am. Even though it was late, there were still quite a bit of a crowd, but not loud obnoxious people - more of the classy type at the venue. 

I liked my drink quite a bit. It's called Bummer & Lazarus. Give it a try :)

Our two drinks with tip came up to $38.
author: Jade F.

description:
Posh, polished and totally swank. Channelling that very British vibe, this most definitely is a St Regis! Attentive service, great snacks, awesome eats and well made drinks. All this and wrapped up into a very cool, sophisticated vibe from the many patrons! 

Looking for an after work cocktail or a liquid libation in a hotel lobby that is probably better then the one you may be staying in... make this your go to place in the Arts District. Chin Chin!
author: Jennie M.

description:
Nice lobby bar in the St. Regis, right on Mission and 3rd. We came here to chat before going into the adjoining restaurant, Ame. 

Modern, understated elegance, but typical hotel lobby bar, except perhaps the people seem slightly more refined than your average hotel bar. Or maybe everyone was dressed up for holiday season parties. Not crowded or noisy, but comfortably busy. 

They do have some drinks they are known for, St. Regis, that is, like their signature Bloody Mary, attributed to them in their New York location back in 1934. 

If you like Martinis and have a couple of Benjamins burning a whole in your pocket, try their $125 Martini. 

Service was attentive, friendly, but restrained, like the rest of the hotel. 

I had a Tanqueray and Tonic. My friend had a Sapphire Martini, slightly dirty. Not the $125 Gin Martini. Not sure of the prices because my generous friend took care of it. I took care of dinner next door, though.
author: Wanugee N.

description:
I love to go here for a mojito or classic martini and the tuna poke appetizer.  The cocktails are impeccable and this is a nice, quiet refuge to have a lovely libation and do some low key people watching.   The staff are incredibly lovely and welcoming.  I especially enjoy when Sandra is on duty, she is a pleasure to be around.

Would not mind a bit more variety on the bar menu or to see it change up a bit more often, but seriously no complaints, the classics are delicious!
author: Kate R.

description: One thing only that matters. The $35+ foie gras Ramen. No HH or deals on drinks or anything just a crowded lobby bar with tons of people the whole day/night.
author: Est K.

description:
The bar is beautiful, there is an open fancy gas fire that is probably 30 feet long. Comfy sofas and a nice view of all the comings and goings in the hotel.

There is a menu of upscale cocktails and not being a sophisticate , the idea of a drink containing egg whites did not gel.

We stayed an hour and had a combination of Chardonnays and Wheat beers, the service was a little slow . My wife wanted to look at the wine list and our server did not come back. When I had finished my beer she did return but she should have returned for her order. 

There was a bar menu and some of the items looked amazing but sadly we had already eaten. 

A very cool spot and well worth a visit.
author: Jeff T.

description: Comfy seating, decent service, and the availability of excellent appetizers (highlight: pork buns) makes this a great spot for an afterwork drink. It's a fairly brightly lit space which means: better for meetings than dates. It can get quite busy, but on a recent Friday happy hour visit we were able to find seating quickly... of course all bets are off when a big conference is in town!
author: Jeremy S.

description: I've been here a few times but the last one had to be one of the more interesting drinking experiences here. Im sitting at the bar with a friend and this crazy drunk dude saddles up to us and starts a conversation. We'd been chatting with the bartender for a while and how he's coming with new drinks and that one of the spirits' websites had featured his recipes. Next thing I know the drunk guy is all over my friend and Im having a good laugh. He tells us he's going to buy us drinks and whips out the American Express Centurion card. Yes the titanium black card. He buys our drinks and tips the bartender $250. He then proceeds to tell us about how his argument with his wife is totally a buzzkill and that he's at the bar to "beat her downer". After his last drink, he stumbles around, and one of the staff basically have to lead him back to his room from the elevator. Crazy patrons, good drinks, and good times.
author: Kim N.

description:
Elegant Spot for a Quality Cocktail!

Had a crazy day at work?  Or a long day of shopping in the city?  Whether you're a tourist or a local, this is a fantastic spot for a cocktail after a long day, a quickie before a night out, or even a first date. 

The bar is as sophisticated and elegant as the hotel. Their Asian-Inspired menu adds a twist to the classics. And, even if there's a crowd, it's quiet, so you can chat or relax by the fireplace.
author: Shaman D.

description:
Ended up here one night when I was reunited with old friends and we really just weren't into all the loud bars in SF on a Saturday night, since all we wanted to do was just sit and catch up all night.

It felt a little uncomfortable when we first went in, because first of all we were all very underdressed (I was showing my friends who were visiting from out of town all day. Naturally we were in comfortable clothes), and also because we were much younger than the overall crowd.

The drinks were expensive, OF COURSE, but we got settled in the comfortable couches with the YUMMY cocktail (lavender gin fizz!) and bubbles and we started feeling good. We ended up staying there til they closed, and I really couldn't have asked for a more comfortable, chill night.

One minus star because of its obvious flaw, the price. But thanks to the price they are able to keep out loud and obnoxious bar crowd, which I really appreciated on that particular night with my old friends. Definitely will be going back when I need another night like that, or for a fancy little night in town.
author: Susie S.

description:
Blasphemy, I know, right?  Before you start hurling refuse at me, gentle Yelper, read on:

I was here Saturday night, and requested the Navarro Vineyards Gewurztraminer Spritzer, neat... you know, just a glass of grape juice in a wine glass.   

The bar snackage was stale and can all be purchased at Cost Plus: rice cracker crescents jacked with chili (skipped that), an abomination that masqueraded as gougeres, and freaky faux edamame puffs.  

The cocktail attendant (is that sufficiently gender neutral and politically correct?) plopped a glass  me with a glass of Pinot Noir in front of me.  

*Scooby Doo Sound*

Cocktail Attendant went Kaizer Soze on me, and so I tried to make eye contact with the bartender at my 9:00.  No dice.  I even swiveled my body, and turned my eyes on to Laser Beam Intensity Setting, which the Cadet will tell you is not at all subtle.

*Crickets*  

Finally, I picked up my glass, and walked up to the bar.  "Hi.  This isn't what I ordered - I ordered the Gewurztraminer."

CA:  "Yes it is."
KD:  "No... it's not.  It's the wrong color.  This is the Pinot Noir."
CA:  "That's what you ordered.  The grape juice."
KD:  "I know what I ordered.  The Pinot was not listed on the nonalcoholic drink menu, ergo I could not have ordered it."
CA:  "I will be happy to show you the bottle that the bartender poured it from.
KD:  *exasperated eye roll of disbelief*
CA:  "See?"  *presenting Navarro bottle of PINOT NOIR*
KD:  "LOOK.  Pinot Noir.  The drink menu says Gewurztraminer."
CA:  "I'll talk to my Manager."

A couple sat down across from me.  The gentleman turned to his companion and said, "Somebody puked in the bathroom sink."

I don't mumble.  Chardonnay... Cabernet, I can understand the mix-up.  But since when do you ever argue with a patron?  For the life of me, I cannot understand why the bartender kept his head down during the entire time I was trying to get my drink transgression resolved.  

The Manager appeared and explained:  Apparently, they'd run out of the Gewurztraminer, so they took the extreme liberty of substituting the Pinot Noir without advising me, figuring grape juice = grape juice.  

How insulting.  

Rightly, they didn't charge me for the drink.

And like that... I was gone.
author: Kim D.

description:
My husband and I were on a special vacation that brought us to San Francisco. Luckily this hotel had an exceptionally good bar and bar tender. After a long day of driving, two outings, and dinner we were tired but not ready to call it a night. So we stopped by the bar. My husband always orders a Vodka Gimlet and I usually get a martini of some kind. So he suggested I try a really good vodka gimlet. We asked the bartender, Jason, if he knew how to make one. All he need was what kind of Vodka! Usually we get what's that? So we were happy. Let me tell you with the fresh squeezed limes, a special simple syrup, and Belevader vodka, in this man's hands...I was drinking the Best drink I have ever had! No joke. It tasted so good and smooth I had to ask if he added something special. Nope just the right mix and some talent of course. Jason was also very entertaining and wonderful to talk to. Some hotel bars are really stuffy and cold. This place all around was not. Still quite elegantly decorated and comfortable at the same time.
Cheers!
Wendie and Dave P.
author: Wendie P.

description:
*drinks only review*

Pretty damn good spot for classing it up for some drinks! We went here with some team members for pre-holiday party drinks on a Saturday evening and this is really a great spot. Drinks are pricey (as to be expected) but generally well made. 

Service was really good at the start but fell off a bit towards the end of our ~2 hours there. Waitresses vanished for a while and it took an inordinate amount of time to get orders in and to get orders delivered -- I'm talking people who showed up had to wait 15 minutes to place an order. 

They have quite the whiskey selection and bartenders make a mean cocktail. Definitely try the Vesper Royale (~$25) if you're a fan of a VERY boozy drink. If there's a drink to avoid, it's the Elderflower Fizz (I think that's the name). Sounds good in theory but the soda water really waters down the taste. Would have been great had they left the soda water out and kept it with only the sparkling wine as the base

And a bonus if you're a points-whore like me: since this is in a Starwood hotel you can earn Starwood points for your spend (which will most likely add up quick)! Just give the staff your SPG number or hang onto the receipt and submit it after the fact.

I'll certainly be back when looking for a change of pace from the usual bars around the office
author: Farhad M.

description:
Date & Time:  Monday June 23, 2008 @ 7:30-ish pm
Company:  Michelle & Mark & Michael
Crowd:  Well-Heeled Asians & Whites from 20-60 Somethings.  Some Colorful Characters @ The Bar like Very Convincing Trannies
Atmosphere:  Quiet Sophistication
Decor:  Swanky. Classy.  Five-Star.  Fireplace.  Paintings.  Sleek Bar.  Great Lighting.  Generous, Nicely Spaced Loungey Seating Areas w/ Deep Velvet Sofas & Low-Tables.  The Ultimate in Luxury.
Service:  Professional- Real Class Act.  As we pulled up, Valets were Very Welcoming & Kept our Car parked out Front where We could See it The Whole Time we were There!  When it was Time to Leave- they didn't Charge us, but of course We left a Tip.  Bartender is Sharp.
Imbibe:  Hangar One
Devour:  Wasabi Peas @ The Bar & Coffee Tables
Note:  Must Make it Past The Lobby One Day
Side-Notes:  A Luminary Resides on the 32nd Floor
author: Genevieve Y.

description:
Nice modern spot for stiff drinks!

I came here during the weekend before Halloween and the place was packed with people in their cleopatra, pilot, phantom of the opera costumes. Despite all the seats being taken, I didn't mind standing around scouring for the next open seat as I chatted with my friend. After 10 minutes, we were able to sit down in oversized chairs and enjoy the wasabi peas and snacks. 

Their cocktails averaged ~$14 and they have one page of selections. Most of the drinks look interesting, i.e. #PumpkinSpiceLatte, Diplomat, and etc. I tried the Diplomat and it was super strong and sweet. 

Overall a really nice hip bar where you can sit, relax, and chat with friends without feeling cramped and screaming over everyone. The price is a little steep but I would come back for an occasion. 

p.s. Entrance to the bar is on the alley and there is most definitely no view. However, if you catch SF during an event, you can enjoy some fancy people watching.
author: Betty S.

description: They charge an additional $3 per drink if you ask for it up without ice or notifying you of the additional charge.  When we requested the manager, he told us it was comment throughout the industry.  I am well traveled nationally and internationally and have never seen this charge.
author: K B.

description: Stopped here twice during the holidays. One evening after dinner for dessert and coffee and another evening with a group of friends. Their dessert was pastry chef delicious. The coffee was so good that cream and sugar were unnecessary. The second visit I ordered a fortified wine I had never heard of or tasted before. The were out but she asked if she could substitute a 20 year old tawny port for the same price as the wine. Wow that was the smoothest port I have ever tasted! It was a generous pour and some of my friends tasted it and also loved it. Love the vibe/decor here. Love the heroic paintings. The waitstaff including the bartender were really nice, friendly and helpful.
author: Liz J.

description:
There are bar snacks... then there are the snacks from St. Regis. Seriously, their complimentary bites have to be the best of it's kind I've ever had in my life. Between the roasted almonds, wasabi peas and these little baked critters that tasted like gourmet Cheez-Its, I could have dined on their goods for hours! If I were a little more intoxicated, I could have definitely seen myself smuggling baked crackers in my pockets for consumption during my cab ride home.

They've got some pretty great drinks to boot. SF is full of fancy pants cocktail bars, and they're no different. Muddled this, fresh picked that. You probably get the idea.

It's also a pretty nice hang in the middle of SOMA. No nonsense and tons of room to lounge around.
author: Ruggy J.

description: Classy ambiance, busy location - home of the original bloody mary! quite the variety of choices for BMs - I chose one that was herbacious and it was that to a T. I liked the italianish one too but I forget what it's called. good place to kick off a day of wandering around San Francisco
author: Caroline K.

description:
The bar menu comes from Ame so it's good stuff with an Asian influence like the tempura poke roll with seaweed and green onions. The tuna and seaweed from the roll sang with umami. Although it didn't have a traditional fluffy tempura coating, it's hard not to like something that's been deep fried to go with cocktails.

For those who complain about the two bar snacks, at least they have bar snacks which are vanishing like water in the desert from the bar scene. Of the eight bars I visited on my SF vacation, this was the only place that had bar snacks.

The drink menu is designed to impress with some pours costing $100+. That's way out of my budget, so I stick with the fanciful $14 cocktails like the Black Ships, Momotaro's Song, Gilded Vice, and Old Man and the Sea. The list periodically changes because the Ame Tremor and Berry Crush from my first visit here are no longer on the menu. The cocktails are consistently too tight and restrained for my style. I prefer drinks that are more open bodied and full.

Both times I've been here, there are plenty of customers (including celebrities), but it's never hard to get a couch.
author: Brian U.

description: Classic, unpretentious but sophisticated, high energy lobby lounge with skilled old school bartenders who can make any drink without problem.  This place is so great, and reliable, it feels like a warm blanket.  All the barkeeps are great, and it's a place I return again and again.
author: Uncle Fishbits Aeneas X.

description: Nice laid back atmosphere. Friendly staff with great tasting drinks. Nice place to relax. Not crowded at all.
author: Mark E.

description: I never write enough, but it's a wonderful place for well made cocktails, good bar snacks and wonderful people watching!
author: Ring Leader D.

description: I love this place. When you want to get all dolled up and have a fancy cocktial in a beautiful setting, this is the place to go. The bartenders are nice (not pretentious), the drinks and wine are good (yes pricey), but to be honest I think a bottle of Anchor Steam is the same price here as it is in the rest of the city. If you like the St. Regis bar, then you'd also like the Pied Piper too (located in the Palace Hotel).
author: Melissa N.

description: Love this place, great people watching, great cocktails, very nice service. So sad Vanessa has left, she was our favorite server.
author: Ron N.

description:
Luxury without pretension. That's totally the St. Regis. It's not trying to convenience you that it's better then that other place down the street, there are no snotty bouncers on power trips, and the bartenders are attentive and cute. The St. Regis Lobby Bar is totally comfortable being its tasteful, classy self.

I had a great time here last night. You can enjoy conversation with the person you're with, instead of hollering over music that's too loud. I love the high ceilings, and the beautiful light fixtures above the bar (props to ashton c. for his great description of the interior). 

And while I expected that the St. Regis would be elegant, I did not expect them to serve absinthe! and who know that our local Hanger One distillery makes not just vodka but also absinthe?! We ordered it and in front of us the bartender set reservoir glasses, delicately slotted spoons with a sugar cube on each, and a classic 1920's fountain of ice water with two spouts. The bartender simultaneously opened the spouts so that water ran over the sugar cube and dissolved the sugar into the absinthe, creating the milky, iridescent cocktails of so much infamy. 

No green fairies last night though.
author: Camille H.

description: Needed a place to chill for a couple hours after the convention ended and before our dinner reservation, and the St. Regis is a close walk away from the Moscone Center. Our server was friendly and attentive and the place is cozy enough, but my god, $16 for an Echigo beer?? $8 for sparkling water? Oh wait, it's a hotel bar. Ok ok, I'm back to reality. I would probably stop by here again if in the area if I needed to conduct business, but if it's just me or I'm with family, I'd probably go somewhere more reasonable.
author: David M.

description:
The St Regis Hotel Lobby Bar epitomizes what a posh hotel lobby bar should be. Large comfy couches, excellent prepared drinks and impeccable service. 

It's pricy, but the drinks are fantastic. Extensive menu of martinis and custom cocktails. Their rendition of a Hot Toddy was really tasty.

It's a quiet and relaxing place for an afternoon or pre-dinner drink.
author: Dave S.

description: Walked down after lunch from the "W' Hotel.  The lounge is really pretty , old Hollywood Glamor .  The service fast and Friendly.  They had sound of Jazz as the background music, which made the atmosphere upbeat.  I had the I had the Visper Martini with Lillet, the James Bond recipe, it was really good with a different taste , all i needed was one.  My friend had the Chardonnay and was pleased. Not to loud but had some noise, so you didn't feel like you were in a dead space.   I will definitely go back with friends from out of town if I am downtown. Once MOMA opens back up that would be a great place to go.
author: Susie S.

description:
I wished i could camp here at the bar all night to enjoy the motion sensor fireplace and sipping champagne.

This is my favorite place to hang out after hours for drinks and to catch up with friends.   I love the appetizers, my favorite is the sushi. 

The cocktails are fantastics!  

I have dined at Ame Restaurant several times, both lunch and dinners.  Overall, this place is great.

happy eating.
author: Truong P.

description:
This is an elegant looking bar. As hotel lobby bar goes this does a pretty good job of looking stylish without being too modern and cliched.

The main problem here is that after work hours it becomes an absolute zoo. I suppose its great if you like that sort of thing but if you want to enjoy a quiet drink in an elegant space you should only go during off hours.
author: Ash S.

description: Hotie Totie.  People who live near the roof pay 12 k a month to live here.  Hot cars and quality service out front.
author: Mot Y.

description: I absolutely love this bar. It's very chic and upscale; perfect to start out a night, or to just grab a few bites and cocktails with friends. The servers are sweet and the drinks are good. My recent cocktail was the gin and sparkling sake drink. Delicious!! They have good tequilas and champagne too. Also, those crunchy wasabi peas (bar bites) are addicting! Love this place
author: Sheeva G.

description:
Came here after the extraordinary game last night. Still elated from a once in a lifetime experience at AT&T park... Giants winning the National League Championship at game 7...  Didn't even let the Cards score, 9-0 unbelievable! We were soaking wet because we wanted to wait till Marco got his MVP award.  I happily agreed to dry off and celebrate our monumental victory against the Cardinals.
Well since we were drinking Blue Moon at the stadium, he knew that a classy place to have a glass of wine to celebrate would undoubtedly place a huge smile on my face. Oh how he knows me so well when it comes to wine and dining. 
The wine was as phenomenal as how I was feeling:  the Giants are in the World Series and I'm in the city and not in Dallas surrounded by Ranger fans!!!
Ok I admit I don't remember the name of the wine, but it was definitely a Petit Syrah blend from France. The ambiance was pretty chill, but soon started to fill up. I've always loved this bar. Last night will definitely be memorable! Go Giants!!!
author: Myra M.

description: AMAZING. The decor, the bartenders, the waitresses. They're all so friendly and the place is chic AF.
author: S W.

description:
Swank, fabulous, and pricey! .... 

Been here a few times for drinks with friends. Recently came back for a coworker get together/ holiday drink time party! You cannot reserve any of the sofas or chairs so plan to get here early if you have a big group. My coworker and I arrived at 430pm during the week and lobby bar was not packed at all. We were able to secure a long sofa and about 2-4 chairs over the course of our time there. 

As soon as we were seated our server came over to greet us and bring us those delicious snacks. Oh and they just don't get you paper napkins here - you get nice black CLOTH napkins... yes so high class. Anyways they have a pretty good speciality cocktail list (I love the kaffir lime martini) and my coworkers enjoyed some of the other drinks that they offered. Our server was very good and came by often to check on us. 

We also ordered food off their bar menu. Menu changes at I think 6pm for diff small snacks. We had fries (OMG so good must order!!!), strip steak to share, sushi rolls, lobster pasta.. all of it was GOOD! 

All in all our group was happy and full! Service, food and drinks were EXCELLENT. Definitely a place for drinks and some bites!
author: Julie F.

description:
The drinks here are really good. The bartenders know their stuff and will suggest or make you a custom drink if you're not sure what you want. 

Also the fireplace thingie is awesome.
author: Richa A.

description: a glass of champagne and that fireplace. my happy place. even happier if someone else is picking up the tab ;)
author: Kelly W.

description: Expensive but drinks are pretty good. Impressive hotel with cool/intimidating murals.
author: Liz L.

description:
The fireplace near the main door is very interesting. Trying to touch the flames would just cause it to go off by itself lol... 

I have been here quite a few times on different occasions. When they first opened, there weren't many people, so I liked the fact that it was relatively quiet and I could enjoy a nice quite evening chatting with my friends. 

Then now they seem like they are always busy and loaded with people on the weekends. Service has somewhat deteriorated. But you better dress somewhat nicely otherwise the waitress might not be too attentive though the bar tenders are always nice. 

It's also a great place to have desert as you can order desert from the menu till 10pm which comes from AME. Most of them are excellent. And so are the snack sized appetizers.

I always order the Yuzu drop and the wine and sake list is also pretty extensive.
author: JET T.

description: Love this place! Very pricey... $14 for a tiny cocktail... But worth every penny! Love Sin Number Six..Yum!
author: Nia Q.

description: Amazing Bloody Mary although we were quite hungover...the big red plastic statue is very odd and the decor is very confusing but the concierge was the most wonderful fellow and we really enjoyed out time with him...he made the stay and the Bloody Mary's made our day!!
author: Well Gnome Chef f.

description: We enjoyed a Hirotini and a Golden Age before dinner and really enjoyed them
author: Jonathan D.

description:
Wow..I can't believe this place got such high ratings. Yes, the decor is nice, in that it's got a line of fire here and there which, don't get me wrong, is very cool, but I think a distinction between decor and ambiance is in order here. 

I say that because, while the decor is nice, the ambiance is a bore. 1) Because this place is in the lobby of a hotel it's very well lit. Two things that should never mix are alcohol and bright lighting. And 2) also because it's part of the hotel, there's a good number of middle aged people waddling around. Again, middle age and alcohol..two things that should never mix at a bar. 

So, empty, this place is very nice because you can focus in on the decor, but the crowd and overall ambiance to this place make me...well..want to hit the bottle.
author: Shreya C.

description:
I love cocktails. I love good looking men. If those come in large quantities, I'm probably having a very good night. If I show up to a bar, and there are attractive men in nice suits, chances are I'm not going to hate it. If I go to a bar, and there are attractive men in nice suits that want to buy me fancy drinks, I'm definitely not going to hate it. 

If you want to go to a place where you may run into the guys from American Psycho, or have a discussion about exchange markets over whiskey on the rocks, the St. Regis is a good spot. The entire crowd looked fantastic - it made me want to go max out my credit card on BCBG and Louboutin. For the ladies, they have a great, varied cocktail list, and the ones I tried were delicious. My favorite was this berry cocktail that was the equivalent of a berry mojito, and I probably drank one too many of them. 

The bartender was very attentive even when it got crowded, and the number 1 thing that I loved: THERE WAS ALWAYS AN OPEN SEAT! Maybe it was just luck, but I never had to stand if I didn't want to. That was major. 

If you're looking for dancing, or at least some hip grooves (wow that sounds like something an old woman would say), the bar at the W is a better spot because they have a DJ. But, if you're looking to start the night at a place a bit more intimate and quiet (and classy) the St. Regis is definitely a good place to hit up.
author: Kelsey E.

description: While the rooms are very nice, the person who cleaned my room also stole my flat iron.  When I contacted the hotel to have them send to me, they said they didn't find it.  I'm sorry, but stuff doesn't just disappear into thin air!  Be careful no to leave anything behind when you stay at this hotel, as you most likely will never see it again!
author: AM H.

description: When I travel to the city I stay at the St. Regis and the lobby bar is a great place to start the night. The ambiance is relaxed with comfortable couches and plenty of bar seating. The bar does get crowded as the nine to fiver crowd rolls in so if you include yourself in that group either sneak out of the office early or prepare to stand all night. The service is attentive and there is a good selection of drinks, my friend had a citrus blossom martini (Svedka Clementine Vodka, Orange Juice, Lemon Juice, Grapefruit Juice, Simple Syrup, Topped with Champagne) which she said was very good. I am a scotch drinker myself and they do have a good selection. I'm not sure about the appetizers because every time I've come here its to have a pre-dinner drink. Drinks are a bit pricey however, its whats to be expected from a hotel lobby bar so don't be shocked when you look at your check.
author: Eric T.

description:
Meeting a friend for a late evening drink at the XYZ bar just proved to me once again that I am too old for that crowd and the noise and the trademark repetitive W  music.  We hustled over to the much more sedate Ame bar at the St. Regis and it was a breath of fresh air.  So serene but not boring - just so much more elegant.  We sat at the bar and enjoyed the beautiful surroundings and the crowd of friendly well dressed tourists and locals.  

The bartender was friendly and welcoming.  Lately I have experienced a happy rash of bartenders at the nicer places all too willing to provide tastes of the various wines on offer until I'm satisfied with my choice.  The St. Regis bar was no different.  You do pay handsomely - $14 for a Sancerre - but it is so nice to feel well taken care of.  A really nice spot for a friendly drink and some excellent bar snacks.  

The experience was so nice I forgot I wasn't actually having a glass of wine at a friends place, and at the end of the evening got up to leave without paying.  I was quickly and amiably reminded of my oversight and paid the bill before Security arrived.
author: Jay Z.

description:
Mmmmm....sexxxxy but chill. 

Walk through the lobby and find inviting leather seating, glass coffee tables, a long strip of blue fire to warm you up on a typical cool San Francisco night, cool lounge music, and the kind of classy ambiance that can only be found at the St. Regis. 

What is there not to like about this place? Weak mojitos (my current poison), unfortunately. But my charming company of about 15 people (great place for groups) liked the various drinks they ordered, so it was probably just the mojitos with a problem. 

This is NOT a meat market like the W. The patrons were decidedly older and more sophisticated. I just ate it up!
author: Virg Y.

description:
I'm in love with this place.  The perfect place to get a good drink, upscale yet chill atmosphere.

I wish I lived in the St. Regis.

Ask for Ali.  She'll hook you up.
author: Genevieve M.

description:
Wow ! I felt so lux and fabulous when I was here for drinks. Try to get to sit at the sofas with tables. Ambiance was super romantic, yet fun for groups to get together. yes the bar snacks, wasabi peas! I would definitely dress up a little more than casual here, just so you can feel little more special!

that night I could definitely smell the folks loading up on whiskey!
author: Maureen M.

description: Steve the bar tender was awesome and filled our wait for AME's reservation with good conversation. I had the drink with the pepper so good!
author: Katie S.

description:
One of the benefits of working for Yelp is that many of my co-workers and I are on an undying quest to always try new places. Luckily for me, everything in this city is fairly new, so every time we hop to a new place, it's a fun reason for me to excited because I then have a new place to report on. 

The St. Regis Lobby Bar is a fave of my buddy Nish N's. We've come here for meetings, for sad news, for a happy drink, a post work drink and even just to shoot the shit and eat wasabi peas. The looks of this place is nice. I wouldn't say it's the warmest or coziest of hotel bars, but really, what hotel bar has a homey feel? 

What it is, is a nice place to catch a glimpse of some business folks using their expense accounts and of course, a guaranteed place to see San Francisco Willie Brown at the same seat at the end of the bar laughing it up. Good stuff.
author: Stephy S.

description: The Lobby Bar is a great place to get a good, strong cocktail....just be prepared to spend some $$$$. It is a very beautiful space and the bartenders are great...I have tried some of the appetizers and they are pretty good...nothing spectacular, but good. Come for the hospitality and ambiance, but make sure to bring your wallet!
author: Julia M.

description:
The perfect place to go for an apres-Sex and the City movie cocktail with your girlfriends. At first, we had designs on the W, but it was filled with Moscone Convention chumps, so we setttled on the S. Regis, a much superior establishment indeed. At $14, the cocktails may be hard on the wallet, but easy on the palate...an infusion of ginger beer, cointreau, and vodka go smoothly down the hatch and worth every drop.  

Waitresses are very attentive and male eye candy easy on the eyes. I had to leave before channeling my inner Samantha and turning my charms on some unsuspecting gentleman...meow indeed.
author: Suzanne R.

description:
Willie Brown met me here :)

So far... Willie Brown, Sean Penn, and Kirsten Dunst have met me. I must either be going to all the right places at the right time, or I'm just that fabulous.

Actually, I'm both. 

This place is a great spot to stop by and have your first drink... or drinks to start off your night. Then head over to XYZ, Roe, Fluid, B Bar or... all of the above. Just make sure you're dressed to super-impress and invite me.
author: Hana N.

description:
Tall ceilings, chic decor and zero character. I've been in a handful of times for cocktails, most recently on a Sunday afternoon for a ladies book club. On a warm sunny afternoon, it was perfect and quite with plenty of room for us to choose a corner to cocktail and chat. 

But otherwise, cocktails are pricey (granted, to be expected at the St. Regis) and somehow even the wasabi peas seemed bland (+1 for free bar snacks, though). Our server seemed generally confused and was unable to come up with even a remotely relevant answer for questions on the wine list and just seemed blank (but at least they didn't stare us down for occupying a corner for two hours). 

In any case, neither the staff nor the setting have any warmth behind them and it's certainly not on my list of must-go places.
author: Erin M.

description:
Ah, the Reeg--where to begin? I love hotel bars, but I generally don't frequent them because of the pricey-ness factor. But, when Vino Venue was shut down due to the faceless corporate asshats who refused to pay the lease for eight months (**SOBS**), one of my favorite "bartenders" from there got a job at the St. Regis Lobby Bar, so I had to check it out. In doing so, I met two of the most fabulous bartenders on the face of the earth--Darius & Rafael. (I have since met Brian, who is also great.) These guys KNOW WHAT THEY ARE DOING, and it doesn't hurt that they are just wonderful and fun to be around. Half the time, I just let them make me whatever they feel like, because they can make some tasty-ass shit that is not on the drink menu. 

What else should you know? Oh yes...the ladies of the evening. The SFPD has actually distributed a photocopy containing various photos of several known high-class sex workers who have been photographed working the area, including The Reeg and the XYZ bar. That was an amusing thing to see. 

Also, as has been mentioned, the drinks are absurdly expensive. I give the place--specifically the bartenders--five stars, but the bar manager just raised the prices of the specialty drinks from $12 to $14. Really? Was that really necessary? Bothersome. - 1 star for that.

The crowd is on the older side, but even though I'm in my late 20s, I like it. This is one of the only places in the city where someone has offered to pay for my drinks, which is just nice every once in a while.
author: Jasmine F.

description:
The best part of the St. Regis hotel lobby bar is the fire pit thingy right up front. We learned that if you put your hand in it, the flames jump down. I think this is to keep the douchebag clientele from seriously harming themselves after getting sauced on $10 - $15 cocktails (really, now!). The second best part is that the staff here will just naturally assume you're a hotel guest and treat you like royalty: there is a lot of door opening-and-holding as well as offers to get drunk girls a cab AND carry their purses AND open the cab door  AND make sure you know where you're going...not that any of that happened to me. 

Drinks are pricey- wine by the glass is in the $15-$20 range and cocktails are not cheap but that's why you should come here with someone who will buy your drinks for you. This will make for a much better experience. The seating is comfortable and cozy and the douches get drunk early and head up to their rooms, which makes relaxing and enjoying one's drinks much easier. And quieter. The bartenders are downright charming and good looking to boot. Plus, you get wasabi peas , almonds, and something else while you imbibe. I am wild about wasabi peas, so I'd probably go back just for those. And the fire game.
author: Autumn K.

description: "The Ruby" is my favorite! Bar is really nice, delicious drinks and good service. I especially love their complimentary bar snacks!
author: Min L.

description:
OK...not the greatest.  gotta give 2 stars for the prices and the atmosphere.  I am a bit more of a cool little gem that is great for just mingling intimately and hanging without any sort of stuffy vibes....so, this place was a bit too pretentious for me and way overpriced for my date (I actually felt bad that we got out of there with my date probably emptying his wallet completely for me).

Company was all good- had a holiday cocktail party with some of my friends....but otherwise, I probably would not go back- sorry St. Regis, Saint of all things overpriced.
author: Stacy L.

description:
3.5 stars

It was nice, it's the St. Regis after all...but hardly a fan.  Located in the lobby, it's very spacious with very high ceiling.  Large paintings on wall - quite interesting combination of Greek and modern.  Fireplace is cool, something I've seen from Candice Olsen's design and what I would like to have at home one day.  Unfortunately those seats were taken but we did get the window seats.  

Very comfy chairs that are extra deep, lean back and you can take a relaxing nap.  To chat with hubby, we both need to lean forward a bit while sipping our drinks and nibbling on wasabi peas.  Of the three little wooden boxes of snacks, our favorite was definitely the wasabi peas.  The cheese crackers were not so good, definitely don't go well with the drinks.  

Service was professional and friendly.  Like the better lounges, they bring the bottle of the wine you ordered and ask if you would like a taste before pouring...just as if you ordered a full bottle at a restaurant.  Hubby had the Forefathers Sauvignon Blanc ($12) and I had the Yuzu Lemon Drop ($14).  It's like a lemon drop but it wasn't great.  

I know we are paying for the name and ambiance but an ok cocktail is that...there are better cocktails at better places.
author: Gloria H.

description: This place is so well done with a touch of minimalist and then over the top rococo style red painting.  They give you free snacks and the place is super loungy.  Bonus, they have a fireplace that is sensitive to any stupid person or drunk person that tries to burn their hand off or something as the whole thing shuts down..  Marvelous.  I can't wait to stay here sometime like all the stars.
author: D B.

description:
I love this bar. Sure, my martini costs $14 here, but it comes with three perfectly skewered pieces of cucumber, a cloth napkin, and little munchies.

But the best part is that is such a nice relaxing place to have a nice quiet drink and chat anytime. Even on a Friday night. Even after 11PM.

I made the mistake of going north of Market last Friday, thinking of the bars as I imagined them on a Saturday or Wednesday evening. The problem is that on a Friday, they all turn into loud, crazy places. And the quiet places close early. So I ended up back at St. Regis where they served until about 1, and since it is a hotel lobby, let you stay as long as you want. I ended up curled up next to the fireplace well past two without any dirty looks.
author: Lauren H.

description:
I live right across the street from "the Reej" and like to pop into the lobby bar from time to time.  It's very sleek and they have a great selection of booze.  As you should expect, the drinks come with a price and the crowd can be interesting, at times.  When I'm here, I like to play a couple entertaining people-watching games with my friends:

1.  "Spot the high-class hooker" - They are easy to spot when they get dropped off adjacent to the valet area in a black SL65 Mercedes ($130K+...P.I.M.P.!).  You get bonus points if you make the spot post-entry.  Tip: professionals get the "nod" instead of a verbal greeting from hotel/bar staff...it's pretty funny because THEY ALL KNOW.  

2.  "Check out that miserable couple"  Bro, I know that spending $500/night for a "romantic weekend in the city" sounds like a great way to salvage your relationship but you should just tie Old Yeller to a tree and spend that money on yourself.  Because when the two of you are crammed into one of those love seats, not talking or making eye contact, it makes the rest of us sad.  But like a car crash, we all have to watch.

The Reej does boast a cool "indoor fire" and occasional b-list celeb sightings so it does round out the experience - as a 5-star hotel, you would expect nothing less.....
author: Ari G.

description: Sexy ambiance..delicious bar snacks...excellent flight of single malt Scotch..hands down my fav hotel bar in the city...
author: Mimi T.

description:
Was late meeting a friend at the hotel's bar thanks to the city's poor cab situation. Grr! My phone was buzzing with text messages.

TXT: Chopchop, nt cool enough to hang alone.
REPLY: Tad late. Mk friends.
TXT: Mthrf*#@!!

A first look at the bar may intimidate the introvert, but it can also be one of the more sophisticated and friendly hotel bars in the city. My friend was kept supplied with Martinis and conversation thanks to amiable, jovial, aim-to-please bartenders. Afterward we made some inquiries as to how far our restaurant was from the hotel. Instead of giving us directions we were ushered to a courtesy car, having us arrive at dinner in a BENTLEY. Some company car. We soaked up every minute of our chauffeured Grey Poupon moment. The experience turned my mild-mannered friend into insta-pimp, who upon exiting the car repeated his new mantra, "Cause that's how Daddy rolls." The bar is representative of the classy, Rock Star service one can expect from the St. Regis!
author: Johnny C.

description:
I can't possibly give the St. Regis Hotel Lobby Bar more than three stars because:

1. A passable Manhattan will cost you $12.50 before tip 
2. The kitchen closes at 10:00 pm
3. The place is a bitch magnet (as are most swanky hotel bars)

Otherwise, it's a pretty good time. There are a lot of couches and comfortable seats. The service was slow, at best, but my buddies and I passed the time with good discussion and excellent people watching from our table in the corner. 

If watching people who are trying to be seen is your thing (and let's face it, everyone likes to do that once in a while),  then the St. Regis Hotel Lobby Bar is definitely worth a visit.
author: Brad L.

description: Working in the hospitality field, I am very particular about hotel bars. This one is deserving of the St. Regis name. Perfect service, comfortable yet upscale, and welcoming atmosphere. The cocktails? Will light you on fire. Yum! I highly recommend taking out of town guests, having an early-evening meeting, or for a romantic pre-dinner drink. You cannot go wrong with a drink here.
author: William N.

description:
Now this is a great place to have a convo. without the crazy YELLING. Yes, YELLLING that is NOT a CONVO. It is a SCREAMING match at some spots that really kills it for any erotic possibilities. Get my vibe?

It is an older crowd, but hey, they have the moolah and are the ones that KNOW how to appreciate quality and gotta respect that in my own groove...oh, yeah....BEWARE of those women that look like "Pros" and I am not talking "Prozac, pills for older men's libido", but hey....was I just imagining it...I don't know, but they sure were suspicious. Yuck...or whatevah...I don't live like them. 

I pay with my own  American Express.
author: miriam b.

description:
If you're looking to impress someone, you could do a lot worse than the bar at the St. Regis. It's very hip and ultra professional, and the atmosphere and decor fit in nicely with the lobby of the hotel. Plus, I like the Wasabi peas they have spread out on the tables and at the bar.

However, if you do hit up the St. Regis, be sure to bring some plastic. Drinks here ARE NOT CHEAP. I had two rounds with a friend recently that set me back nearly $50.

Oh, and the bar tenders aren't the fastest or the friendliest of sorts. But considering this is a swanky hotel bar, the staff is fine.

It's an older crowd, which means you won't have to put up with the riff-raff that plagues other spots in the area. And every time I go there, I usually spot a celeb or two (Willie Brown, Downtown Julie Brown, etc.)... Okay, maybe not an A-lister, but you get the point...
author: Mitch S.

description:
This place is not really a hotel bar. It's more of a lobby where you can get drinks. I took a seat on one of the couches that was weirdly located back to back with another couch. 

Overheard:

Older-put-together-lady: I mean, she sits on her asssshh and gets, *hic*and gets $80K a year just because, just because she's married to you. I mean, I work *ice clinking*, ....I work my ass off at your*hic*goddamn office for $45K and what do I get? Nuffing. *hic* Nothing. 

Older married CEO type: Why must it allllllways end up here between us?*heavy sigh**large gulp**sound of eyes rolling*

Boyfriend: Jesus Christ! Heineken's here ar.....
Me: Shhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhh!

OPTL: Bechaussse, because, I loff you, and that bitch gets $80K a goddamn yeahar jhust because she*muffled speaking through gin glass**clink**clink**

OMCT: Oh sweet Jesus. 

BEST. HOTEL NON-BAR. EVAR.

Oh, and by the way, Heineken's there are $9.
-1 star.
author: Leah S.

description:
Eye candy, beautiful decor, great wine and drink selection, good service, yummy nibbles, awesome fire treatment.

Oh, and beware the valet parking cost.  I was there for a couple of hours the other night and paid $45 for parking (plus tip).
author: Kimberly Q.

description: It is fun to stop by for a cocktail.  Their food used to be delicious and is now ho hum.  It is nice to have a relaxing place that is not a dark typical  bar.
author: T H.

description:
If you ask anyone that knows me to pick my favorite bar in town, there's no hesitation they would pick St. Regis right away.

I love this place.  Proper cocktails, excellent service, awesome atmosphere, comfortable seats.  What else do you need when you're in the mood for a good drink?

One question always haunts me about this place though...the murals? Really?
author: Sean W.

description:
**I'm adding another star because I have been wanting to go to a plush bar lately and the first one I though of was St. Regis so obviously it made an impression.

Two point five stars for the opulent decor and intriguing vibe. The drink prices however are ridiculous. Having read reviews here I was expecting some mind blowing cocktails, ummm no, mediocre at best. I don't mind shelling out for a GREAT drink but these were meh. Please, come over to my house and I will SHOW you how to make a Cosmo sir (or lady, I really didn't see the bartenders). 
So yeah I guess if your drink is very straight forward, or you need to impress someone, this place would suffice. I would take my LA cousin here. Like I said, its plush, and we all know how much Cait Z likes her plush and fancy-ness.
I would add another star for the wonderful company I was with but honestly, does the St. Regis have anything to do with that? No
author: Catty C.

description:
When I finally leave San Francisco, if I ever leave San Francisco, I'm going to send to my best friend Eddie an invoice for the difference in price between cocktails at the St. Regis (~$14) and at, say, a regular haute/hip bar ($9, let's call it), x the # of drinks I've had at the St. Regis (ah, like 125 at this point? 150?). Because if it weren't for him calling me one night during his Brief Sojourn in San Francisco Without His Wife (who was the advance party for their move to Lansing, MI (med school for her, otherwise, yeah, why would anyone ever?))--but like I was saying if it weren't for him calling me one night to squawk in my ear some variant of, DUDE! You HAVE to come down here!, I never would've considered myself near liquid enough to, you know, go to the hotel lobby of a St. Regis for drinks with any regularity, if by "regularity" I can be understood to mean, "ever."

But he did, and I went, and now I'm several hundred dollars (further) in the red (than I otherwise might be).

Oh I know what you're thinking: What, your correspondent has no self-control? 

But you need to understand: it's so beautiful here.
